Posts.Content: Decipher results back. I'm at a .73 which is in the genomic high risk category. I will have a consult in 5-6 weeks with URO to discuss best path forward. My URO does not use the uPSA so the baseline will be my first post-op PSA . Is adjunctive radiation started immediately or is there a wait time for surgical recovery? Too many considerations are in play. One day at a time... PS Djin, thanks for the heads-up on the GRID report. It has been requested.
Posts.Signature: 71 years old Agent Orange exposure PSA 12.70 H 07/12/18 PSA 2011 3.79 Biopsy 10/2/2018 Gleason grade 4+4 score 8 grade group: 4 CT & Bone Scan No metastatic disease Da Vinci RP 12/18/2018 PATHOLOGY REPORT TUMOR Acinar adenocarcinoma Histologic Type Gleason Pattern % of Pattern 4 70% % of Pattern 5 5% Primary Gleason Pattern 4 Secondary Gleason Pattern 4 Tertiary Gleason Pattern 5 Total Gleason score 8 Intraductal Carcinoma (IDC) Present Extraprostatic Extension (EPE) Present, nonfocal Seminal Vesicle Invasion Present, right Margins Uninvolved by invasive carcinoma Lymph nodes Uninvolved by invasive carcinoma Primary tumor pT3B Decipher test result: .73 High Risk 2 month uPSA .006
Posts.Title: Adverse pathology results Decipher ordered

Posts.Content: My Urologist has ordered the Decipher Genomic test for me. I don't expect that will change any prognosis but am hopeful it will give me a more detailed analysis of my PCa. Will Decipher help determine when any adjuvant treatments should be done? When is it likely to be metastatic? Can any cancer specific mortality estimates be made for undergoing treatment vs no further treatment? Thanks Keith

Posts.Title: Adverse pathology results Decipher ordered

Posts.Content: Hey Sean, My cath came out yesterday. Having some leakage, especially if I stand up or move. If my concentration lapses I lose some urine. Today is the beginning of the new world order. I got some of those Depends, you know, the package with the studly, verile guy half my age who just left the gym. That made me feel better. The next ones will be the ones with the older guy with a little paunch. That'll make me feel better too! Im on my 3rd pair of briefs for the day. Im encouraged by the fact that I can stop and start and have a sense of urgency. Best of luck! Keith
Posts.Title: Catheter Out and all clear

Posts.Content: I just read the earlier Busby thread and that answers many of my questions I am 90 days post-op RP. 60 day uPSA .006 I am having a good recovery. Minimal incontinence, ED still an issue but possible with VED. I am seeing my radiological oncologist next week to discuss if I should have adjuvant radiation or wait until i have any rise in PSA. Question is should I have RT now or wait? Thanks, Keith

Posts.Content: Djin, My primary care is at the VA in Minneapolis but I went outside for my RP as I didn't want to wait the additional 6 weeks to have the RP. I am now going back to the VA because of the potential costs with ongoing care as I only have Medicare A & B. I will be seeing my outside urologist/surgeon in 2 weeks so will get his opinion too. The radiology department in Minneapolis VA has a good reputation so I will see what their opinion is. Thanks! Keith PS Medicare was kind to me and I will have out of pocket costs less than $2,000 with total cost being $72,000

Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: Let me begin by saying that I am overwhelmed by the comments after my first post on the forum. They all were welcoming, compassionate, insightful and savvy. There was hard data, links to information and relevant studies, and thoughts based on personal experience and knowledge. It was clear that the consensus opinion was simply, “sooner is better”! To that end I took a few steps today. I investigated the possibility of being referred to an outside urologist for a second opinion or the possibility of treatment. There is the Veterans choice program which evolved from the fact that vets were forced to wait unreasonable amounts of time before getting appointments at the VA. This also included those where the distance from a VA facility created an undue hardship for the veteran or the VA is unable to provide care in a reasonable amount of time. I don’t meet the criteria for this because I was able to get the “initial” appointments within 30 days. The need for subsequent treatment does not alone have the 30 day window as a qualifying factor. The 30 day rule does not apply in the waiting period for treatment after the initial exam. Also I was offered a surgery date of December 13th for open surgery but wanted to have the daVinci robotic surgery with first available date being January 29th which is over 8 months from my original request for a urology consultation. The fact that treatment was offered within a reasonable amount of time may have been a factor in not being sent out for Community care. I made an appointment with the most highly rated/recommended urologist in the Twin Cities for an initial appointment on November 19th. He has done well over 4000 procedures and was one of the first to be trained and certified in the daVinci process. His surgical schedule could be as early as the last week of December. He does not take VA insurance but does accept Medicare. I don’t know what kind of co-pays and costs there might be but it is a secondary factor. I still have my VA schedule as an option. I’m in Washington DC thru next Tuesday as I like being here at the Vietnam Wall for Veterans Day. When I get home I’ll dig into some of the links and studies suggested. A few questions asked of me; I’m 71 years old and was in Vietnam from August 1967 until June 1968. My PSA was 12.7 in August 2018 but hadn’t had any recent PSA tests as my chronic BPH was thought to account for any increases in PSA. Again I can’t thank all of your for your welcoming, compassionate responses to me first post. Despite my unintentional qualification for membership it’s my kind of club! Best regards, Keith
Posts.Title: No hurry, should I worry

Posts.Title: No hurry, should I worry

Posts.Content: Recently DXd PSA 12.7 Gleason score 8 (4+4) Bone scan and CT scans no evidence of metastatic spread Consulted with radiological oncologist and urologist and have decided to have robotic radical prostatectomy. I am scheduled for Jan 29, 2019 and am concerned about the wait. Should I be? Is it a no hurry, no worry situation. The waiting has been the hardest part of this whole process; Appointment, tests, and waiting for results has been difficult . Im a Vietnam veteran and have had agent orange exposure. Also Dxd with CLL in 2014, currently stage zero, no symptoms. My care is through the VA and I have been very satisfied thus far. Thanks in advance! Keith
